controlled, liquid-fueled rocketry |significant_awards = |signature =}} 'Robert
Hutchings Goddard' (October 5, 1882 – August 10, 1945) was an
American professor, physicist, and inventor who is credited with creating and
building the world's first liquid-fueled rocket, .{{cite web
  | url = http://www.google.com/patents/about?id=ikBJAAAAEBAJ&dq=1,102,653 title
  | = Rocket Apparatus publisher = Google | work = Patents accessdate = 2010-05-
  | 01}} which he successfully launched on March 16, 1926. Goddard and his
  | team launched 34 rockets {{cite web url
  | = http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/goddard.htm title = Goddard publisher =
  | Astronautix}} between 1926 and 1941, achieving altitudes as high as
  | and speeds as high as 885 km/h (550 mph). {{cite web url =
  | http://history.nasa.gov/AAchronologies/1961missile.pdf title = A Chronology
  | is Missile and Astronautic Events 1686â1961 | format = PDF publisher =
  | NASA/U.S. GPO}}

Goddard's work as both theorist and engineer anticipated many of the
developments that were to make spaceflight possible. {{cite journal
|doi=10.2307/3106375 |title=The Enigma of Robert H. Goddard |author=Hunley, JD
|journal=Technology and Culture |volume=36
  | date = Apr 1995
  |issue=2 |pages=327â50 |jstor=3106375}} Two of Goddard's 214 patents â
  one for a multi-stage rocket design (1914), and another for a liquid-fuel
  rocket design (1914) â are regarded as important milestones . toward
  spaceflight. His 1919 monograph [[#A Method of Reaching Extreme Altitudes|A
  Method of Reaching Extreme Altitudes]] is considered one of the classic texts
  of 20th-century rocket science. .{{cite journal |url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/goddard/pdf/110902main_FS-2001-03-017-
  GSFC.pdf |title=Robert H. Goddard: American Rocket Pioneer
  | publisher =NASA | format = PDF
  |journal= Facts |date=FS-2001-03-017-GSFC |pages=1â3}} Goddard
  successfully applied three-axis control, gyroscopes and steerable thrust to
  rockets, all of which allow them to be controlled effectively in flight.

Goddard received little public support for his research during his lifetime.
Although his work in the field was revolutionary, he was sometimes ridiculed in
the press for his theories concerning spaceflight. As a result, he became
protective of his privacy and his work. Years after his death, at the dawn of
the Space Age, he came to be recognized as one of the founding fathers of modern
rocketry. {{Citation
